terms.definition: The decrease in a vehicle's value over time due to age, mileage, and wear.
terms.example: New cars lose 20-30% in Year 1, about 60% by Year 5. A $40K car = $16K after 5 years.

terms.definition: Complete cost: purchase, financing, insurance, fuel, maintenance, repairs, and depreciation.
terms.example: In {{STATE_NAME}}, monthly payment is only part‚Äîadd {{STATE_SALES_TAX}}% sales tax, registration, insurance.

terms.definition: A secured loan where the vehicle is collateral. You make payments over 36-72 months until you own it.
terms.example: Average new car loan rate in {{STATE_NAME}}: {{STATE_AVG_AUTO_LOAN_RATE_NEW}}%

terms.definition: A contract to use a vehicle for 24-36 months by making payments, then return it or buy it.
terms.example: Lower payments but mileage limits, no ownership, perpetual payment cycle.

leftPanel.title: "I Can Afford $399/Month!"
paragraphs: A student in {{STATE_NAME}} making $2,500/month sees a car payment of $399 and thinks it's affordable. But that's not the whole picture...
When you add {{STATE_NAME}}-specific costs like insurance, fuel, registration, and maintenance, the true monthly cost is closer to $800+/month.

highlightBox.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Financial experts recommend total vehicle costs stay under 15-20% of take-home pay.
� Always budget for state-specific fees beyond the sticker price!

layoutData.title: New Cars Lose Value Fast
paragraphs: Depreciation is the silent cost of vehicle ownership. A new car loses value the moment you drive it off the lot, and the steepest decline happens in the first 2-3 years.
bulletPoints: Year 1: Loses 20-30% of value (drive off lot = instant loss)
Sweet Spot: 2-3 year old used car avoids steepest decline

keyPoint.text: üí° Strategy: Buy a 2-3 year old certified pre-owned vehicle and let someone else absorb the steepest depreciation.

leftPanel.title: Shorter Terms = Less Interest
paragraphs: Longer loan terms reduce monthly payments but dramatically increase total interest paid.

36 months: Higher payment, ~$2,600 interest
60 months: Medium payment, ~$4,400 interest
72 months: Low payment, ~$5,300 interest

highlightBox.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è With 72-month loans, you may owe more than the car is worth for 4+ years!

infoCard.title: Being "Underwater":
items: Owe more than car is worth

layoutData.title: Second Largest Purchase of Your Life
paragraphs: For most people in {{STATE_NAME}}, vehicles are the second-largest financial decision after housing. The financing method you choose can result in tens of thousands of dollars in difference over your lifetime.
bulletPoints: Monthly Cash Flow: High payments limit saving for emergencies and retirement
Opportunity Cost: $100K+ could have been invested instead
Credit Impact: Auto loans affect your credit score and debt-to-income
Financial Flexibility: Owning outright = no payment if income changes
Life Goals: Vehicle overspending delays home purchases, retirement
Compound Effect: Every $100/mo saved now = $120K over 30 years

keyPoint.text: üéØ The Goal: Transportation that meets your needs at the lowest total cost, freeing money for wealth-building.

leftPanel.title: What Else Could That Money Do?
paragraphs: Money spent on a car depreciates immediately and generates no return. The opportunity cost is often the most overlooked factor.
What if instead of a $500/month car payment, you drove a reliable used car (paid off) and invested that $500 monthly?
At 7% average return for 30 years, you would have accumulated approximately $600,000.

scenario.name: Mia's Buy-and-Keep Strategy in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Mia considered leasing a new SUV for $450/mo but instead purchased a certified pre-owned sedan for $18,000 in {{STATE_NAME}}.
After 4 years she owned it outright. For the next 3 years, she drove payment-free while saving $350/month‚Äîthat's $12,600 saved or invested!

scenario.name: James's Perpetual Lease Cycle in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: James loved having the newest truck with latest features. He leased in {{STATE_NAME}} for $499/month + $2,000 down on a 36-month lease.
When it ended, he leased again: $525/month + $2,000 down for another 36 months.
Over 6 years: $36,864 in payments + $4,000 in down payments + $2,000 in overage fees = $42,864 with NO asset.
